newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot gas prices plummet ahead of mild weather.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot gas prices plummet ahead of mild weather.

text.p: U.S. spot natural gas prices plummeted Friday as well above-normal temperatures were forecast for most of the U.S. this weekend, sources said.

December Gulf Coast prices fell an average of 40 cents to as low as $3.00/mmBtu as temperatures were forecast to be at least 10 degrees above normal this weekend in the East, Midwest and Texas. Early deals were confirmed done around $3.20.
A lack of swing activity contributed to the volatility, traders said.
January gas at the Gulf Coast notionally was quoted around $3.15-3.20, down sharply from Thursday's levels at $3.70.

At the New York city-gate, where buyers are anticipating much warmer weather over the next few days, early weekend deals were done at $3.80, but shortly before nomination deadlines prices were down in the $3.40s, falling about 50 cents from Thursday.
In the Appalachian region, prices ranged anywhere from the $3.60s early to the $3.20s late, down an average of 35 cents from Thursday.
Midcontinent prices were for the most part in convergence with Gulf values early but then slipped into the $2.60s late, pressured by mild temperatures now in most of the region and a lack of buyers.
In west Texas, Permian gas prices were widely talked in the $2.60-3.25 range, down from Thursday's $3.30-3.35 trading range.
Prices in south Texas were also widely discussed, with late deals done in the $2.70s and $2.80s, as well above-normal temperatures left buyers disinterested in the market.
